For diagnostic tests, the specimens used for acute haemorrhagic fever syndrome are whole blood, serum or plasma for ELISA and RT-PCR, and skin or tissue specimens from fatal cases for immunohistochemistry. These specimens must be handled with extreme caution to prevent contamination and infection.

RDTs may result in both false positive and false negative test results, so it is recommended to use a nucleic-acid based diagnostic assay, such as GeneXpert, to confirm the RDT result. In settings where PCR testing is available, antigen detection RDT s for VHDs should not be used for routine management of VHDs. However, they may have utility in settings without laboratory infrastructure and where specimens cannot be rapidly transported to a diagnostic laboratory, if their benefits and limitations are understood. When collecting specimens from suspected VHF patients, it is important to collect until specimens have been collected from 5 to 10 suspected cases. Specimens should be handled and stored with extreme caution, as they may contain infectious agents. It is recommended to wear protective clothing and use barrier precautions when handling specimens. For ELISA or PCR tests, serum or tissue specimens should be refrigerated or frozen, respectively. Immunohistochemistry specimens can be fixed in formalin and stored at room temperature for up to 6 weeks. Formalin-fixed specimens may be transported at room temperature. Laboratory confirmation of VHF cases is not routinely available, so advance arrangements are usually required for diagnostic services. It is recommended to contact the appropriate National authority or WHO for assistance with laboratory confirmation.

Anthrax is a rare but serious disease caused by bacteria called Bacillus anthracis. It can be contracted through contact with infected animals or their products, such as wool, hides, or meat. In humans, it typically causes severe illness and can be fatal if not treated promptly.

Anthrax has an incubation period of 1-7 days, but can be longer in some cases. The possible forms of human infection include cutaneous (skin), gastrointestinal (digestive) and pulmonary (lung). Anthrax is a zoonotic disease that can be transmitted from infected animals to humans through direct or indirect contact with animal products. It is important for public health officials to monitor outbreaks and control programs in order to prevent the spread of this serious disease.

If a single case of Anthrax is suspected, it's important to report the case-based information immediately to the appropriate levels, which are the public health sector and animal health sector. Standard barrier precautions should be used for all forms, including gloves, gowns, face shields, and respiratory protection if there is a risk of aerosols. The patient should also receive supportive care and antibiotics such as Penicillin V, procaine penicillin (uncomplicated cases), or penicillin G (severe cases). It's important to collect specimens safely to confirm the case and conduct joint investigations with both public health and animal health sectors. Vaccination is required for animals when exported or imported in humans, and selective preventive vaccination may be considered in case of occupational exposure. Thorough history taking should be done to determine if there is occupational exposure, as unnecessary administration of antibiotics might lead to antimicrobial resistance (AMR). Standard infection control precautions are sufficient and should be used when managing the patients, with particular attention paid to body fluid spills which should be managed promptly and thoroughly. Personal protective equipment should be used in situations where there is potential for splashes and inoculation injuries. Any incidents should be reported immediately. The community should also be mobilized for early detection and care, and proper burial or cremation (if practiced) of dead bodies (humans and animals) should be conducted. Community education about the confirmed case, how the disease is transmitted, should also be provided.

Additional information and resources on Anthrax can be found at the World Health Organization's website (www.who.int), as well as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website (www.cdc.gov/anthrax). These websites provide up-to-date information, guidelines, and recommended protocols for diagnosis and treatment of anthrax in humans and animals.

The forms of Anthrax that pose a higher risk for explosive outbreaks are cutaneous anthrax and inhalation anthrax. Cutaneous anthrax is more common and can be easily transmitted through skin contact with infected animals or contaminated materials, while inhalation anthrax is rarer but more deadly as it affects the respiratory system.

Suspected cases of Anthrax should be reported to both the public health sector and animal health sector as soon as possible. Immediate reporting is important because it allows for prompt investigation and control measures to prevent further spread of the disease. It also helps in identifying potential sources of infection and implementing appropriate treatment and vaccination strategies.

Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain. The standard case definitions for uncomplicated and severe malaria are based on clinical or laboratory evidence of vital organ dysfunction. Uncomplicated malaria is defined as any person living in an area at risk of malaria with fever or history of fever within the previous 24 hours; without signs of severe malaria, who tests positive for malaria by either rapid diagnostic test or microscopy. Severe malaria is defined as having clinical or laboratory evidence of vital organ dysfunction.

This method helps in detecting possible epidemics and taking necessary measures to control them.

Early detection and control of malaria epidemics are ensured through laboratory testing, prompt treatment with appropriate anti-malarial drugs, investigation into the cause for the increase in cases, community education on detecting symptoms and seeking medical attention, and ensuring that children under 5 years old receive proper care according to IMCI guidelines. The components of programs aimed at eradicating malnutrition include improving access to nutritious food, promoting breastfeeding, providing micronutrient supplements, and implementing community-based interventions such as nutrition education and counseling. Additionally, addressing the underlying causes of malnutrition, such as poverty and lack of healthcare, is crucial for successful eradication efforts.

The goal of nutrition surveillance is to monitor the prevalence and distribution of malnutrition in a population, identify risk factors for malnutrition, and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at preventing or treating malnutrition. This information can be used to inform public health policies and programs that aim to improve the nutritional status of individuals and communities.

If more than 20% of children are underweight, there should be a focus on breastfeeding support and nutrition education for both mothers and children. If more or equal than 15% of low birth weight babies are less than 2.5 kg, targeting interventions such as improved antenatal care for women and neonatal care for infants should be implemented. Home-based therapy with oral rehydration should be encouraged, and community education about safe water practices should be conducted. If there is a twofold increase in cases or deaths from diarrhoea with severe dehydration compared to previous years, it may indicate a need for improved health worker performance in managing cases and implementing IMCI guidelines. The most vulnerable populations in terms of malnutrition are children under five years old and pregnant or lactating women. These groups are at a higher risk of developing severe malnutrition due to poor nutritional status, inadequate access to clean water and sanitation, lack of education on proper feeding practices for infants and young children, and repeated infections.

The standard case definition for malnutrition in children under five is based on indicators such as weight for age, mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), and birth weight. If more than 20% of children are underweight or if a child is found to have MUAC less than 11.5 cm, further investigation should be conducted and the child should be referred to a therapeutic feeding program.

A maternal death is defined as a woman who dies during pregnancy or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration and site of pregnancy. This includes deaths related to ectopic gestation and abortions.

According to the World Health Organization, approximately 287,000 women die annually due to complications during pregnancy and childbirth globally. This is a significant issue that requires attention and action from governments, healthcare providers, and communities around the world.

The lifetime risk of maternal death in sub-Saharan Africa is high, with an estimated 1 in 17 women dying during pregnancy or childbirth. This is due to a combination of factors such as lack of access to healthcare, malnutrition, and inadequate infrastructure. In Malawi specifically, the risk is even higher, with an estimated 1 in 25 women dying during pregnancy or childbirth.

The standard case definition for maternal death is when a woman dies while pregnant or within 42 days of the delivery or termination of the pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy but not from accidental or incidental causes. This definition helps in monitoring maternal mortality rates and identifying high-risk areas for maternal mortality.

The data on maternal deaths should be analyzed and interpreted by looking at the number of deaths that occurred in a specific location, date, and time frame. This information can help identify patterns and trends in maternal mortality rates over time. Additionally, it is important to consider factors such as age, gravidity, parity, and medical history when analyzing this data. By understanding these factors, we can better understand the causes of maternal deaths and work towards reducing them.

These complications are often preventable with proper medical care, but lack of access to healthcare facilities and trained personnel in rural areas contributes to the high mortality rate.

The surveillance for maternal deaths should be conducted in health facilities and community health centers. This is because these are the places where most women receive antenatal care, which can help identify potential risks and complications during pregnancy. Additionally, many maternal deaths occur during delivery or in the immediate post-partum period, making it important to monitor these locations for any signs of distress or complications.

The alert threshold for maternal deaths at a health facility is significant because it helps monitor maternal mortality rates and identify underlying causes and contributing factors that can inform program decisions. It also allows for evaluation of programs aimed at reducing maternal mortality. Additionally, it ensures timely reporting to district authorities and review by maternal death review committees.

The SDG reporting in 2030 differs from the MDG approach in terms of maternal mortality reduction goals by setting a specific number for each country to achieve, rather than a percentage. This means that countries will be held accountable for achieving a certain number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, rather than just reducing them by a set amount. Additionally, the SDGs require active surveillance and counting of maternal deaths at both community and facility levels, which was not required in the MDGs.

The data on maternal deaths should be analyzed in the district where the majority of the deaths occurred. This is important because it allows for a more targeted approach to addressing the underlying issues that contribute to these deaths, such as access to healthcare and education about safe pregnancy practices. Additionally, analyzing the data at the district level can help identify any patterns or trends that may be specific to certain areas, which can inform future interventions and policies aimed at reducing maternal mortality rates.

The extent of the problem of maternal mortality globally is that it remains too high, with more than 500,000 women dying every year as a result of complications during pregnancy and childbirth. This is especially true in sub-Saharan Africa where a woman's lifetime risk of maternal death is 1 in 22, compared to 1 in 8,000 in industrialized countries. The leading cause of maternal deaths in sub-Saharan Africa is haemorrhage, and unattended births are particularly risky, especially in rural areas with limited access to healthcare facilities. To achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for maternal health, it is essential to improve the coverage and quality of maternal health care services and address the factors contributing to these deaths through active surveillance and accurate reporting.

Measles is a highly contagious viral infection that causes fever, rash, and respiratory symptoms. It spreads through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes. In Malawi, measles outbreaks can occur in areas with low vaccination rates, leading to severe illness and death among children. To prevent the spread of measles, it's important to get vaccinated and report suspected cases promptly.

The risk factors for measles outbreaks include lack of vaccination, poor sanitation, malnutrition, and overcrowding. These factors can weaken the immune system and make individuals more susceptible to contracting the disease. It is important to address these issues in order to prevent future outbreaks.

The diagnostic test for measles is a laboratory test that detects the presence of the virus in a patient's body. Specimens should be collected as soon as possible after the onset of symptoms, preferably within three days, and then again at least seven days later. This will help to confirm the diagnosis and determine if the person has been infected with the virus.

Specimens should be prepared by collecting 1 to 5 ml of venous blood, separating the blood cells from the serum, and storing the serum in a clean glass test tube. The specimen should then be transported using appropriate packaging to prevent breaking or leaks during transport. Results are usually available after 7 days. If as few as 2 out of 5 suspected measles cases are laboratory confirmed, the outbreak is confirmed. To avoid bacterial overgrowth, ensure that the serum is poured into a clean glass test tube and stored at 4 C to 8 C to prevent bacterial growth.

The reference for responding to measles outbreaks in measles mortality reduction settings is the World Health Organization's guidelines for investigation and control of foodborne disease outbreaks, specifically their section on measles.

Additionally, there are technical guidelines for integrated disease surveillance and response in the African region available from the World Health Organization (WHO).

Dromedary camels are the major reservoir host for MERS-CoV and humans are infected from direct or indirect unprotected contact with infected dromedary camels. However, the exact role of dromedaries in transmission of the virus and the exact route(s) of transmission are unknown. The virus does not seem to pass easily from person to person unless there is close unprotected contact, such as occurs when providing care to a patient. Health care associated outbreaks have occurred in several countries, with the largest outbreaks seen in Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, and the Republic of Korea. Approximately half of human cases of MERS have been attributed to human-to-human infections in health care settings. Monkeypox primarily occurs in the rain forests of West and Central Africa. The primary animal reservoir for the virus is unknown, but it has been detected in a range of small mammal species, particularly rodents, and monkeys. Communities living in these regions need to be educated about avoiding direct contact with animals, especially wild species.

Monkeypox is transmitted between humans through prolonged contact with respiratory droplets and contact with lesions or bodily fluids that contain the virus. It can also be spread by direct contact with infected animals, particularly rodents, monkeys, squirrels, dormice, and non-human primates. To prevent transmission in endemic regions, it's important to avoid direct contact with wild species and thoroughly cook all animal products before eating.

Some countries that have reported human cases of Monkeypox are: - Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) - Sierra Leone - Liberia - Cote d'Ivoire - Nigeria - Cameroon - Gabon - Republic of Congo - Central African Republic - Sudan (in South Sudan)

Event-based surveillance is considered sensitive because it relies on the screening of all available information to detect any event happening in the community, such as unusual disease or deaths in humans or animals, unusual clustering of cases, events, conditions in the community, and environmental conditions. This means that EBS requires a high level of sensitivity and specificity to accurately identify potential public health threats. The key activities conducted by district-level focal points during humanitarian crises include coordinating community risk mapping activities, ensuring reporting sites are aware of thresholds for acute outbreaks or events, identifying and mobilizing resources for emergency prevention and control, monitoring the use of resources before, during, and after the event, and managing major public health activities such as immunization, clean water projects, family planning clinics, feeding centers for malnourished children, and refugee camp health activities.

The responsibility for ensuring the availability of quality-assured WHO-approved RDT kits during a crisis should fall on both national governments and international organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO). National governments are responsible for maintaining adequate stocks of these kits in their healthcare systems, while international organizations like the WHO can provide guidance and support to ensure that these kits meet the necessary quality standards. Additionally, it is important for all stakeholders involved in crisis response efforts to work together to establish effective supply chains and logistics networks to ensure that these kits are available when they are needed most.

The feedback should be disseminated through the provided feedback platforms on mobile phones, which are accessible to the affected community and stakeholders. This will allow for effective engagement with all parties involved in the public health crisis.

Regular supervision and support are essential to enhance surveillance functions at all levels because they ensure that the necessary resources, training, and guidance are provided to those responsible for monitoring and responding to health threats. This helps to maintain a high level of accuracy and effectiveness in detecting and reporting outbreaks, as well as coordinating responses across different sectors and regions. Additionally, regular supervision and support can help identify areas for improvement and provide opportunities for learning and innovation in the field of public health surveillance.

The critical aspects of feedback and dissemination in the context of IDSR during a humanitarian crisis include timely reporting, accurate data analysis, and effective communication with all stakeholders involved. It is important to have a clear understanding of the situation on the ground and prioritize the most pressing health concerns. Additionally, having a designated coordination mechanism can help ensure that information is shared efficiently and effectively.

Outbreak preparedness in crisis-affected populations differs from standard practices in several ways. Firstly, the existing national IDSR framework may be compromised or diminished due to the acute or complex emergency situation, which requires WHO and partners to take a lead role in enhancing outbreak preparedness efforts. Secondly, key sections of the emergency preparedness and response plan should include designated coordination structures, including committees, matrix of stakeholders and partners supporting health activities, epidemiology and surveillance activities, social mobilisation, risk communication and community engagement strategy, operational actions according to expected phases of the epidemic, laboratory specimen collection, handling, transportation, processing and information management, case management, immunization strategies, rapid containment activities and additional methods if rapid containment fails, psychosocial support for all affected, including community members and responders, capacity building, logistics, environment, water and sanitation, decontamination of patients and environment, monitoring and evaluation of the outbreak or event, resource mobilization and procedures to relocate or mobilize resources to support response, mapping of hotspots.

Outbreak investigations should be undertaken by rapid response teams at national and sub-national levels that have been established as part of the national IDSR framework. These teams should follow existing IDSR outbreak investigation guidelines adapted to address the unique needs of crisis affected populations. The investigations should include laboratory studies such as microscopy, culture, antimicrobial susceptibility testing, serotyping, serological investigation, molecular detections and identification, genomic sequencing, and specimen collection and transportation kits for epidemic prone diseases.

In crisis-affected populations, alert and epidemic detection thresholds are used to initiate response. These thresholds are normally expressed in terms of the number (or proportion) of cases of a disease and the critical point (threshold) beyond which action must be taken. Trained health care personnel should always determine the alert and epidemic thresholds. Statistical tools and methods may be applied to determine the alert and epidemic thresholds. Thresholds for alerts and epidemic prone diseases, conditions or events are shown in Section 11 of these 3rd Edition Malawi IDSR Technical Guidelines.

An exit strategy is important during the recovery phase of a crisis because it helps to ensure that resources are used effectively and efficiently, and that the affected population's needs are met in a timely manner. It also helps to prevent further harm or damage from occurring, and can help to build resilience for future crises.

The main objective of an outbreak investigation in the context of IDSR during a humanitarian crisis is to control the outbreak and reduce morbidity and mortality. This involves determining the cause of the outbreak and identifying those at risk so that appropriate control measures can be implemented. Rapid response teams are established as part of the national IDSR framework, and dedicated and trained teams are identified in acute and complex emergencies. The investigation should follow existing IDSR guidelines adapted to address the unique needs of crisis-affected populations.

The additional risks in crisis-affected populations include limited access to healthcare facilities, lack of resources, and increased vulnerability to disease outbreaks. To address these risks, it is important to strengthen existing or form new multi-sectoral outbreak control teams at national and subnational levels with designated roles and responsibilities for each team member. Health, Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and other relevant cluster partners should support outbreak response activities in crisis affected populations. Additionally, preparedness efforts should be integrated into the existing national IDSR framework at national and sub-national levels, with WHO leading the efforts and supported by partners. During acute or complex emergencies, WHO working with health cluster partners should take lead to enhance outbreak preparedness. Key preparedness efforts include participation of other key actors such as private organizations, business entity association groups, traditional healers, food vendor associations, and others who might influence response activities. Response activities for particular outbreaks or public health problems may include managing cases, conducting emergency vaccination campaigns, providing relevant chemoprophylaxis and vaccination for health workers, improving access to clean water, improving safe disposal of human and animal waste, controlling vectors, and reducing exposure to mosquitoes and other vectors.

Countries should approach the exit strategy during the recovery phase by re-establishing all the IDSR structures and focal points in the crisis affected populations, with roles and responsibilities designated for each team member as set out in the IDSR outbreak response guidelines. Health, Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and other relevant cluster partners should support outbreak response activities in crisis affected populations.

Indicators are measures used to track progress towards achieving a set of objectives or targets. They provide information on how well a program is performing and can be used to evaluate its effectiveness. In Malawian public health, indicators are commonly used to monitor the performance of surveillance systems. These include disease-specific indicators such as AFP (antibody detection) and measles cases, as well as overall recommended performance standards for reporting completeness. By using indicators in accordance with national goals and specific plans, we can track progress towards achieving these objectives and make informed decisions about how to improve the quality of our surveillance systems.

The selected data for measuring indicators assist in improving the surveillance system by providing a way to track progress towards achieving set targets and objectives. By analyzing routine surveillance data using indicators, we can identify areas where improvements are needed and take corrective actions. This helps ensure that the surveillance system is effective in detecting and responding to public health threats.

Indicators play a crucial role in assessing the performance and quality of a surveillance system. They provide measurable data that can be used to track progress towards achieving program objectives and goals. By using indicators, public health officials can determine whether their interventions are effective and make necessary adjustments to improve outcomes. Additionally, indicators help ensure that resources are being used efficiently by identifying areas where improvements can be made. Overall, the use of indicators is essential for ensuring that surveillance systems are meeting national standards and providing accurate information to inform decision-making.

Monitoring indicators should be established to monitor core surveillance functions when there is a need to track progress towards achieving specific goals or targets related to disease prevention, control, and elimination. Common methods of indicator-based surveillance include using standardized definitions and criteria for selecting indicators, collecting data on these indicators from various sources such as health facilities, laboratories, and community surveys, analyzing the data to identify trends and patterns, and using this information to inform decision-making and resource allocation.

Cases should be recorded on case-based surveillance reporting forms in order to collect data for analysis and monitoring of disease outbreaks. This helps to identify patterns and trends in the spread of diseases, which can inform public health interventions. The form should include basic information such as the patient's name, physical address, and location (e.g., village or neighbourhood, GVH, TA, district) for locating information.

The core functions monitored at the district level include ensuring sources of data are available, monitoring the timeliness and completeness of monthly reporting, identifying problems and taking action, and evaluating the functional core capacity for implementation of IHR (2005). Additionally, there is a focus on One Health and IDSR in relation to Disaster Risk Management.

In the context of Malawian public health, it is important to have a system in place that ensures accurate and prompt identification and reporting of cases for surveillance. This responsibility falls on various stakeholders such as healthcare providers, laboratories, and local authorities. They should work together to collect data, analyze trends, and report any suspected or confirmed cases to the appropriate authorities.

The examples of indicators for monitoring core surveillance functions at the district level include the proportion of complete surveillance reports submitted on time to the district, the proportion of cases of diseases targeted for elimination, eradication and any other disease selected for case-based surveillance reported with case-based forms or line lists. These indicators are used to assess the effectiveness of surveillance systems in detecting and responding to outbreaks of infectious diseases.

In investigating and confirming suspected cases or outbreaks in the context of IDSR, there are several steps involved. First, a rapid response team is established to conduct investigations promptly. These teams should be trained and equipped with the necessary tools to collect information from the field, such as conducting physical examinations and collecting lab samples. The investigations should follow existing IDSR outbreak investigation guidelines that have been adapted for crisis-affected populations. Once an outbreak has been confirmed, a response can be initiated, which may involve notifying higher levels of government and implementing measures to contain the spread of the disease.

The monitoring of preparedness for epidemics contributes to the overall effectiveness of IDSR at the district level by ensuring that there is a system in place to detect and respond to outbreaks quickly. This includes having trained personnel who can investigate and respond to outbreaks promptly, as well as having access to necessary resources such as laboratory support and data analysis tools. By monitoring preparedness for epidemics, districts can be better equipped to prevent the spread of disease and protect public health.

An effective feedback system in the context of IDSR at the district level involves monitoring, evaluating and supervising the implementation of the system. This includes collecting data on indicators such as the proportion of districts producing regular epidemiological bulletins, the proportion of feedback bulletins received from national levels, and the proportion of health facilities with at least one IDSR technical support supervision visit in the previous quarter. The feedback is then used to modify the next action and improve the performance of the system.

Indicator-based surveillance is commonly used to monitor and evaluate public health programs, such as disease outbreaks or vaccination campaigns. It involves using specific indicators to track progress towards program goals and identify areas for improvement. Common methods include electronic reporting systems, manual data collection, and laboratory testing.

It is important to monitor the timeliness and completeness of monthly reporting because it allows for effective monitoring of public health issues. By ensuring that reports are submitted on time and contain all necessary information, we can identify trends and patterns in disease outbreaks and take appropriate measures to prevent further spread. This helps to protect the health and well-being of individuals and communities.

Incomplete or late reporting in IDSR can have serious consequences on public health. It can lead to delayed detection of outbreaks, which can result in the spread of diseases and increased morbidity and mortality rates. Additionally, incomplete or late reporting can hinder effective response efforts by limiting the availability of accurate information for decision-making at all levels.

The attributes of the surveillance system, such as monitoring events from community-based surveillance, supportive supervision, feedback, and evaluating effectiveness of IDSR strategy, contribute significantly to the overall quality of IDSR activities at the district level. These attributes help in identifying gaps and areas for improvement, which can be addressed through periodic evaluation assessments.

The timeliness and completeness of reporting are crucial factors in detecting and responding to public health threats in IDSR. Immediate reporting of case-based information allows for early detection of unexpected or highly pathogenic events, which can be investigated and responded to promptly. Completeness of reporting ensures that all relevant data is captured and analyzed accurately, leading to more effective decision-making and response strategies.

FETP residents play an important role in evaluating the surveillance and response systems of IDSR. They monitor the quality of surveillance activities at community level, supportive supervision and feedback for improving IDSR activities, evaluate effectiveness of the performance of IDSR strategy, and implement Cross Border activities in the context of IDSR.

The Ministry of Health should monitor the detection and notification of immediately reportable diseases or events. This is because they are responsible for ensuring that all cases of these diseases, conditions, or events are reported within 24 hours. Additionally, they are in charge of weekly reporting to ensure timely communication with other stakeholders. Finally, monthly reporting allows them to track trends and patterns over time.

The completeness of reporting sites submitting surveillance forms can be evaluated by comparing the number of reports submitted to the expected number based on historical data. Additionally, feedback from the reporting sites can also provide insights into any challenges they may have faced in submitting their reports on time.

The crucial dimensions of completeness in surveillance are timely reporting by all sites submitting surveillance forms and meeting deadlines for each level. This ensures effective monitoring of public health indicators.

The completeness of case reporting can be monitored and improved in the context of IDSR through various measures such as ensuring an adequate supply of data collection and reporting tools at surveillance sites, providing on-site training to health care workers on using standard case definitions for priority diseases, monitoring performance indicators like timeliness and completeness, and disseminating feedback.

The completeness of reporting sites submitting surveillance forms should be monitored at both the national and subnational levels. This includes ensuring that all required information is included on the form, such as case definitions, laboratory results, and contact tracing data. Additionally, it is important to monitor whether all reports are submitted within the designated time frame to ensure timely detection of outbreaks.

Community-based surveillance plays a crucial role in improving the overall quality of the surveillance system by involving local communities in monitoring and reporting disease outbreaks. This approach helps to ensure that information is collected accurately, timely, and comprehensively, which can lead to more effective response efforts. Additionally, community involvement can help to build trust between health workers and the public, which is essential for successful disease control programs.
